topics.body:
My math class's online grading system is a dick.

I tried to get ahead of myself by doing a little extra work to boost my grade up a bit, and then it puts down "Zero" grades for upcoming assignments to be graded, which in turn, bring my grade down a bit. (Which they shouldn't.)

Goddammit my parents are egging me to pass that class, but how can they trust me when the system doesn't play nice?
topics.author: 536f7a11636872666e2d0000

topics.body:
"@Gizoid101":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5512105963687237b4f70400#post_5512105963687237b4f70400
The single biggest thing I hate in mass media is anticlimax.

My thought process:
At first, "Hmm; the manga sounds overhyped, but it might be alright"
"*hearing all the fights are anticlimactic* Yeah; fuck no."

"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5512110463687222b91c0900#post_5512110463687222b91c0900

topics.author: 5062d6f17f123b3e16001184

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5512110463687222b91c0900#post_5512110463687222b91c0900
There is a difference between unintentional anticlimax (Mass Effect 3 comes immediately and unwelcomely to mind) and comedic anticlimax, which is both intentional and arguably one of the purest forms of comedy.

Comedy is all about subverting expectations afterall, and if nothing else anticlimax does that right.

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5512128e63687229f1030b00#post_5512128e63687229f1030b00
And there in lies the problem with things like One Punch Man and trying to gauge them objectively. Comedy is a completely subjective genre. What's funny to one may not be funny to another.
